content.title: Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)
content.summary: Surgical revascularization procedure using arterial and venous conduits to bypass coronary artery stenoses, providing improved blood flow to ischemic myocardium and survival benefit in select patients
key_points: LIMA to LAD is the gold standard graft with 90% patency at 10 years
Saphenous vein grafts have lower long-term patency (50-60% at 10 years)
CABG superior to PCI for: left main disease, 3-vessel CAD with diabetes, complex anatomy
On-pump (cardiopulmonary bypass) vs off-pump (beating heart) surgery
Perioperative mortality: 1-2% for elective CABG, higher with emergency/cardiogenic shock
Complete arterial revascularization (bilateral IMA) improves long-term outcomes
DAPT after CABG: aspirin lifelong, clopidogrel x1 year if ACS presentation

statement.text: Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) is a surgical revascularization procedure that uses arterial (internal mammary artery, radial artery) and venous (saphenous vein) conduits to bypass coronary artery stenoses. CABG provides survival benefit over medical therapy and PCI in patients with left main disease, three-vessel disease (especially with diabetes or reduced EF), and complex coronary anatomy. The LIMA-to-LAD graft is the cornerstone of CABG with excellent long-term patency.
statement.formal: CABG indications = Left main ≥50% OR 3-vessel CAD + (diabetes OR LVEF <50% OR SYNTAX >22) | LIMA-LAD = gold standard | SVG patency < arterial grafts

explanation.intuition: When coronary arteries are severely narrowed or blocked, the heart muscle beyond the blockage receives inadequate blood flow. CABG creates new pathways (bypasses) around the blockages using vessels harvested from elsewhere in the body. Think of it like building a new highway to bypass traffic congestion. Arterial grafts last longer because they are designed to handle arterial pressures, while vein grafts are adapted to the arterial environment and tend to fail over time.
explanation.key_insight: The LIMA-to-LAD graft is the single most important determinant of long-term outcomes after CABG. Its use reduces mortality by 40% at 10 years compared to vein grafts alone. The LAD supplies the largest territory of myocardium, and the LIMA has unique properties (resistance to atherosclerosis, endothelial function) that maintain patency. Maximizing arterial revascularization with bilateral internal mammary arteries further improves outcomes.
explanation.technical_details: CABG is typically performed via median sternotomy with cardiopulmonary bypass (heart-lung machine). The heart is arrested with cardioplegia solution, allowing anastomoses to be performed on a still heart. Off-pump CABG (OPCAB) maintains cardiac motion using stabilizers but has similar long-term outcomes. Hybrid revascularization combines minimally invasive LIMA-LAD with PCI to other vessels.

definitions_glossary.coronary_artery_bypass_grafting: Surgical procedure creating new conduits to bypass coronary artery stenoses
definitions_glossary.lima: Left internal mammary artery - gold standard graft for LAD with excellent long-term patency
definitions_glossary.rima: Right internal mammary artery - used for bilateral IMA grafting to improve outcomes
definitions_glossary.saphenous_vein_graft: SVG - vein harvested from leg used as bypass conduit; lower long-term patency than arterial grafts
definitions_glossary.radial_artery: Arterial conduit from forearm; patency intermediate between IMA and SVG
definitions_glossary.cardiopulmonary_bypass: Heart-lung machine providing circulation while heart is arrested for surgery
definitions_glossary.off_pump_cabg: OPCAB - CABG performed on beating heart without cardiopulmonary bypass
definitions_glossary.cardioplegia: Solution used to arrest and protect the heart during on-pump surgery
definitions_glossary.anastomosis: Surgical connection between graft and native coronary artery
definitions_glossary.sternotomy: Surgical incision through the sternum to access the heart
definitions_glossary.syntax_score: Angiographic scoring system quantifying coronary complexity; higher scores favor CABG
definitions_glossary.complete_revascularization: Bypassing all significant stenoses; improves long-term outcomes
definitions_glossary.hybrid_revascularization: Combination of surgical (LIMA-LAD) and percutaneous (PCI) revascularization
definitions_glossary.graft_patency: Percentage of grafts remaining open at a given time point

pathophysiology.mechanism: CABG bypasses coronary artery stenoses by anastomosing conduits (arteries or veins) distal to the blockage. Blood flows from the aorta (or subclavian for IMA) through the graft directly to the coronary artery beyond the stenosis. This restores myocardial perfusion, relieves ischemia, improves contractile function in viable but hibernating myocardium, and reduces angina.

graft_physiology.arterial_grafts: IMA maintains endothelial function, releases nitric oxide, resists atherosclerosis. In-situ IMA is flow-responsive.
graft_physiology.venous_grafts: SVG exposed to arterial pressure develops intimal hyperplasia and accelerated atherosclerosis. Early occlusion from thrombosis; late failure from disease.

graft_patency_rates.rima: Similar to LIMA when used appropriately
graft_patency_rates.radial_artery: 85-90% at 1 year, 80% at 5 years (improved with calcium channel blockers)

class_i_survival_benefit: 3-vessel CAD with or without proximal LAD involvement
2-vessel CAD with proximal LAD stenosis and reduced LVEF or ischemia
Significant CAD with reduced LVEF ≤35% (viability required)
class_i_symptom_benefit: Significant CAD with unacceptable angina despite optimal medical therapy
cabg_preferred_over_pci: Left main disease with complex anatomy

preoperative_assessment.cardiac: Coronary angiography, echocardiography, viability testing if reduced EF
preoperative_assessment.surgical_risk: STS risk calculator estimates mortality and morbidity
preoperative_assessment.conduit_assessment: Allen test for radial artery; vein mapping if needed
preoperative_assessment.comorbidities: Diabetes control, renal function, carotid disease, pulmonary function

on_pump_cabg.technique: Median sternotomy, cardiopulmonary bypass, cardioplegic arrest
on_pump_cabg.disadvantages: Inflammatory response, potential neurologic injury, longer recovery

off_pump_cabg.technique: Beating heart surgery with stabilizer devices
off_pump_cabg.advantages: Avoids bypass-related complications, may reduce stroke
off_pump_cabg.outcomes: Similar long-term mortality to on-pump in experienced centers

graft_selection_strategy.lima_to_lad: Mandatory in nearly all cases (unless contraindicated)
graft_selection_strategy.bilateral_ima: Consider in younger patients (<70), non-diabetics; improves survival
graft_selection_strategy.radial_artery: Second arterial conduit; use with CCB for antispasm
graft_selection_strategy.svg: Remaining targets after arterial conduits used

postoperative_management.antiplatelet: Aspirin 81-325 mg lifelong; DAPT if ACS presentation
postoperative_management.risk_factor_modification: Smoking cessation, diabetes control, BP management

definition.@value: Surgical revascularization procedure using arterial and venous conduits to bypass coronary artery stenoses and restore myocardial blood flow

skos.scopeNote: Covers indications, graft selection, surgical techniques, and postoperative management; compares CABG vs PCI
skos.example: A 62-year-old diabetic man with 3-vessel CAD (80% proximal LAD, 90% LCx, 70% RCA) and SYNTAX score 28 undergoes CABG with LIMA-LAD, radial artery to LCx, SVG to RCA; discharged on aspirin, statin, and cardiac rehabilitation

learning_objectives: Identify patients who benefit from CABG over medical therapy or PCI
Apply SYNTAX score and clinical factors to guide revascularization strategy
Explain the importance of LIMA-LAD and arterial grafts for long-term outcomes
Compare on-pump vs off-pump CABG techniques
Prescribe appropriate postoperative antiplatelet and risk factor management
clinical_pearls: LIMA to LAD is the single most important graft - 90% patent at 10 years
CABG > PCI for left main, 3-vessel CAD with diabetes, complex anatomy (SYNTAX >22)
Bilateral IMA improves survival but increases sternal wound infection in diabetics
SVG failure: early = thrombosis; late = atherosclerosis. Aspirin + statin reduce failure.
SYNTAX score guides decision: ≤22 = PCI reasonable; >22 = CABG preferred
Complete revascularization improves outcomes - bypass all significant stenoses
Radial artery needs CCB or nitrate to prevent spasm

board_yield.usmle_step2: High - indications, CABG vs PCI decision
board_yield.cardiology_boards: Very High - detailed indications, graft selection, landmark trials

common_misconceptions: All multivessel CAD should have CABG (false - depends on anatomy, diabetes, EF)
CABG cures coronary disease (false - disease progresses; lifelong risk factor modification needed)
Vein grafts and arterial grafts have similar patency (false - arterial grafts far superior)
Off-pump is always better (false - similar outcomes in experienced centers)
